tossups.question: A 2009 paper by McCarty, Poole, and Rosenthal is titled for the relationship between this practice and political polarization, but concludes polarization is more due to population sorting. Nicholas Stephanopoulos developed the “efficiency gap” metric for measuring the extent of this practice. In June 2019, the Supreme Court ruled that claims about this practice are non-justiciable by invoking the (*) political question doctrine in Rucho v. Common Cause. “Cracking” and “packing” are two methods for this practice. Some states have tried to avoid this practice by establishing independent commissions, and others are limited in this practice by the Voting Rights Act. For 10 points, name this practice whereby political boundaries are adjusted to favor one political party over another.
tossups.answer: gerrymandering [prompt on legislative redistricting; prompt on electoral manipulation]

tossups.question: Dietrich Brandis’s conservation efforts failed to amend the Forest Act of 1865, a pivotal juncture in this country’s ecological history according to This Fissured Land. Women in this country hugged trees as part of the Chipko movement. The “Save the Seeds Movement” opposed the introduction of IR-8 rice into this country, an innovation criticized by an ecofeminist in The Violence of the (*) Green Revolution. A methyl isocyanate gas leak from a Union Carbide pesticide plant in this country killed thousands in 1984. The essay “The Greater Common Good” rebukes this country’s government for building a dam on Ādivāsī land. The Bhopāl disaster in this country occurred six months after Operation Blue Star foiled plans to cease grain exports from Punjab. For 10 points, name this country where Sikh bodyguards assassinated Indirā Gāndhī.
tossups.answer: India [or Republic of India or Bhārat Gaṇrājya]

tossups.question: In his set for this musical, Boris Aronson used a giant mirror to reflect the audience onstage. One version of a number in this musical features an elderly bespectacled man sitting in a garden while those around him sing, “The morning will come when the world is mine.” A boy soprano sings that anthem on a record played by a highly sexualized character in a West End revival of this musical. Bob (*) Fosse’s film version of this musical names its male lead Brian instead of Cliff, who is roommates with a hedonistic Liza Minelli character who sings, “life is just [this musical’s title].” Alan Cumming began the trend of dropping one character’s coat to reveal a pink triangle and yellow star at the end of this musical that is based on Isherwood’s Goodbye to Berlin. The Emcee sings “Willkommen” to open, for 10 points, what musical about the rise of the Nazis as seen by the Kit Kat Klub?
tossups.answer: Cabaret (The unnamed number is “Tomorrow Belongs to Me,” and the Liza Minelli character is Sally Bowles.)

tossups.question: One character in this novel refers to his vision of a bare, flaming tree in an apocalyptic landscape as “the place where God does not exist.” This novel’s narrator finds a diagram with intersecting lines representing reason, imagination, and memory, as well as several videos of an adult film star named Melinda. In a chapter of this novel framed as a transcript, a government official is shot at the (*) New Life Pastry Shop. After returning to Frankfurt, Germany, this novel’s protagonist is killed by a follower of a militant named Blue. Sunay Zaim dies during a production of The Spanish Tragedy in this novel, whose protagonist is forced to leave the border city of Kars without his lover Ipek. For 10 points, the poet Ka investigates the suicides of “headscarf girls” in what novel by Orhan Pamuk?
tossups.answer: Snow [or Kar]

tossups.question: One enhancement method in this technique occurs via mechanisms like the “cross” and “solid” effects. That method, which is the basis for CIDNP (“kidnip”), uses microwave irradiation to dynamically transfer the polarization of an electron reservoir to the sample in this technique. Mei Hong studies membrane proteins using a form of this technique often enhanced through magic angle spinning. AB and AX label complex patterns observed in this technique. The (*) field is held constant while sweeping through the frequency in this technique’s “continuous-wave” mode. Protons that are more strongly deshielded by neighboring electrons appear downfield in this technique and have a higher chemical shift. For 10 points, name this technique that determines organic structures by using a magnetic field to split nuclear spin-states.
tossups.answer: NMR spectroscopy [accept nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; prompt on magnetic resonance imaging or MRI; accept ssNMR or solid state nuclear magnetic resonance; accept proton NMR, H1 NMR, or C13 NMR]

tossups.question: Baba ben Buta, a teacher with this trait, advised Herod to tear down and rebuild the Second Temple as penance for massacring other rabbis. On the night that he buried a man in Nineveh, one man obtained this trait after he fell asleep under defecating sparrows. In the Gospel of John, the disciples ask Jesus if a man obtained this trait because of his sins or his parent’s sins. Tobias uses a fish’s gallbladder to (*) cure his father, Tobit, of this condition. A man named for this trait is cured in Bethesda after Jesus spits on him in the Gospel of Mark. Ananias (“ann-uh-NYE-iss”) cures Saul of this trait, which a vision of Jesus had inflicted upon him as he was traveling to Damascus. For 10 points, Matthew 11:5 (“eleven-five”) declares that people with what trait will receive sight?
tossups.answer: blindness [accept answers like being struck blind or eyes turning white or whiteness] (Baba ben Buta was blind because Herod placed a garland of porcupine hide on his head.)

tossups.question: Harold R. Kaufman pioneered the development of a device for this task based on electron bombardment after abandoning a duoplasmatron design. Deploying an electrodynamic tether downwards while connected to a power supply lets it be used for this task. This task is performed by NSTAR and NEXT, two technologies that use ionized xenon. A quantity that measures the efficiency of this task is symbolized I-sub-sp and given in units of seconds. One design uses the radiation (*) pressure on giant mirrors to perform this task. Because supersonic flows violate Bernoulli’s principle, this task relies on nozzles that increase the width of the flow channel. The Tsiolkovsky equation describes how this task is accomplished by expelling mass at a high exhaust velocity. For 10 points, what task is performed in space by thrusters?
tossups.answer: rocket propulsion [or rocket acceleration; accept thrust until “thrusters” is read; prompt on space travel by asking, “What task necessary for space travel is performed by the clued devices?;” prompt on liftoff or launching by asking, “What task is performed once the spacecraft is in air?”]

tossups.question: A lengthy conga solo introduced this musician in the debut concert of a multinational ensemble that he led at Royal Festival Hall; that ensemble is the United Nation Orchestra. Two measures of syncopated, broken F octaves mimic this musician saying the title of another of his songs. With Sarah Vaughan, this musician recorded a vocal version of a standard that he called “Interlude,” whose B section is left unresolved since it quotes Arthur Schwartz’s “Alone Together.” A 2-plus-3 (*) clave (“CLAH-vay”) rhythm appears in one of several songs that Gil Fuller and Chano Pozo wrote for this musician based on Afro-Cuban mambo. A jazz style that this musician pioneered with Charlie Parker is exemplified by his songs “Groovin’ High” and “Salt Peanuts.” For 10 points, what bebop musician played standards like “Manteca” and “A Night in Tunisia” with a bent trumpet?
tossups.answer: Dizzy Gillespie [or John Birks Gillespie] (The F-sharp octaves mimic Gillespie saying “Salt Peanuts.”)

tossups.question: In a story titled for one of these animals from the collection Beethoven was One-Sixteenth Black, the narrator watches one of them die while working at her typewriter. A crablike animal who is boiled and then escapes a house without his legs was created as a reference to one of these animals in the story “Father’s Last Escape” by Bruno Schulz. Another book refers to one of these animals as “ungeziefer,” or “unfit for sacrifice.” A couple discusses their (*) “young and voluptuous” daughter on a tram ride after the death of one of these animals, who prizes a picture of a woman in furs. Upon awakening from “uneasy dreams,” one of these animals is supplied with food by his sister Grete. For 10 points, Gregor Samsa transforms into what kind of animal in Franz Kafka’s The Metamorphosis?
tossups.answer: cockroaches [accept bugs or insects or vermin; accept dung beetles] (The lead-in refers to “Gregor” by Nadine Gordimer.)

tossups.question: After this conflict, Joaquín Costa formed the Regenerationism movement, which embraced anti-imperialism and attacked corruption characteristic of caciquismo politics. Military defeat in this conflict coincided with the end of the political careers of Práxedes Mateo Sagasta and the assassinated Antonio Cánovas, mainstays of el turno pacífico. One side’s warmongering in this conflict was influenced by the “worst insult” in its country’s history, the (*) de Lôme letter. The reconcentration policy of General Valeriano Weyler, nicknamed “the Butcher,” prompted this conflict, after which the Generation of ‘98 formed to address a collective national trauma based on the loss of Guam, Puerto Rico, and Cuba. For 10 points, name this conflict, sparked by “yellow journalism” after the 1898 explosion of the USS Maine.
tossups.answer: Spanish-American War [or Guerra hispano-estadounidense]

tossups.question: One of these animals covers a model’s genitals in a costume for the funhouse Dream of Venus. An artist was allegedly stopped from adding mayonnaise to an outfit printed with sprigs of parsley and one of these animals. Cecil Beaton took pre-wedding photos of Wallis Simpson in a dress that depicted one of these animals and was created by Elsa Schiaparelli. One artist questioned why he could ask for a grilled one of these animals, but not a particular (*) electronic device. A plaster one of these animals adorns the mouthpiece of a telephone created by Salvador Dalí. This is the first of two animals that title a steel wire and sheet aluminum sculpture that hangs in the MoMA stairwell. For 10 points, a trap for what animal is paired with a Fish Tail in the title of a mobile by Alexander Calder?
tossups.answer: lobsters [accept Lobster Dress; or Lobster Telephone; or Lobster Trap and Fish Tail]

tossups.question: Vincent Harlow argued the occurrence, around 1783, of a “swing to the east” in this political entity, creating its “second” phase. The posited hegemony of “gentlemanly capitalism” within this political entity declined after World War I. For covering up a scheme that aided the expansion of this political entity, a politician earned the nickname “screenmaster-general.” The expansion of this political entity was linked by Alfred Thayer Mahan to having command of the (*) seas. By claiming the “growth of national consciousness is a political fact,” Harold MacMillan foreshadowed the fracture of this political entity in the “Wind of Change” speech. Eric Williams links capitalism and slavery through the triangle trade within the Atlantic possessions of this empire, on which “the sun” apocryphally “never sets.” For 10 points, name this historical colonial power, now replaced by the Commonwealth.
tossups.answer: British Empire [accept answers like British Africa or British colonies; prompt on Britain; prompt on the Commonwealth until read; prompt on British Navy or Royal Navy or British East India Company by asking, “The Navy and the East India Company were used to expand what political entity?”]

tossups.question: This character calls Phoebus’s chariot “Phibbus’ car” while reciting a poem about “raging rocks and shivering shocks.” This character alludes to First Corinthians in a monologue describing an experience “past the wit of man” that “the eye of man hath not heard” and “the ear of man hath not seen.” This character exclaims, “Thus die I, thus, thus, thus,” and, “now die, die, die, die, die,” after pretending to (*) stab himself. This character orders around Peaseblossom and Mustardseed, the servants of a woman who falls in love with him upon being awakened by his singing. This member of the rude mechanicals portrays Pyramus in a play-within-a-play staged for the Duke Theseus. For 10 points, name this weaver who is given the head of an ass by Puck in A Midsummer Night’s Dream.
tossups.answer: Nick Bottom [or Nick Bottom; prompt on Pyramus until read by asking, “What character is portraying Pyramus?”]

tossups.question: John Mbiti argues that African thought traditionally only recognizes “actual” rather than “potential” forms of this concept. Simone Weil uses coming out of Plato’s cave as a metaphor for the “renunciation” of this concept. This is the second title concept of a book that rejects the “vulgar” conception of it in favor of a unity of “ecstases,” and suggests that its ontological structure mirrors that of care, or sorge (“ZOR-guh”). Our inner states are ordered with respect to this concept, which is a form of pure (*) a priori intuition, according to the Critique of Pure Reason. The A- and B-series used to model this concept were introduced by JME McTaggart, who argued for its unreality. Along with Being, this concept titles Martin Heidegger’s magnum opus. For 10 points, give this concept over which moments and events are extended.
tossups.answer: time [or sein; prompt on temporality; prompt on past, present, or future]

tossups.question: The problem of assigning these things is equivalent to finding an n-coloring of an interference graph. A reorder buffer is used to rename these things to implement out-of-order scheduling in Tomasulo’s algorithm. Read-after-write and write-after-read hazards occur when these things are accessed prematurely. In early hardware, these things were implemented as a cascade of flip-flops, and they held operands for (*) arithmetic logic units. In C, frequently-used variables are sometimes declared to be stored in these locations, where they cannot be addressed. These locations occupy the highest rung of the memory hierarchy and are 64 bits wide in most x86 architectures. For 10 points, identify these memory units found on the CPU, which are smaller and faster than caches.
tossups.answer: processor registers

tossups.question: Constructs like cooperation with ongoing behavior can be used to assess sensitivity in this practice, as enumerated in a longitudinal Baltimore-based study. Dorothy Dinnerstein called for changes in this practice in The Mermaid and the Minotaur, arguing that the status quo resulted in distrust of female power. Responsiveness and demandingness were used by Diana Baumrind to categorize types of this practice. Leo Kanner developed a discredited theory linking (*) autism to this practice. Anxious-avoidant and other attachment styles resulting from this practice were identified in Mary Ainsworth’s “Strange Situation.” An authoritative style of this practice is associated with more positive outcomes for its subjects later in life. For 10 points, name this practice of attending to the needs of one’s offspring.
tossups.answer: parenting [or answers like child-rearing or interacting with children; accept mothering or maternal care or fathering or paternal care; prompt on attachment by asking, “What practice is attachment an outcome of?”] (The first clue refers to Ainsworth’s Maternal Sensitivity Scale.)

tossups.question: According to Banking on the State, this country’s loose central banking regulations shaped by Riad Salameh increased the risk of financial meltdowns. In September 2021, this country decided to give cash aid to needy families in US Dollars. Lectures in “The Egg” in this country denounced a proposed tax on WhatsApp calls and morphed into the October Revolution. Equal political representation for religious sects in this country’s government was ensured by the (*) Taif Agreement. In August 2020, Hassan Diab declared a national day of mourning one day after an accident at the port complex in this country’s capital displaced hundreds of thousands and magnified a growing disillusionment with Hezbollah. For 10 points, name this country, where a large explosion of ammonium nitrate leveled the Port of Beirut.
tossups.answer: Lebanon [or Lebanese Republic or Lubnān or al-Jumhūriyya al-Lubnāniyya] (Hicham Safieddine wrote Banking on the State.)

tossups.question: In 2020, this organization’s leader Michael Brune made a post denouncing the racism that its founder espoused in books like A Thousand-Mile Walk to the Gulf. This organization was accused of promoting eugenics after it published Paul Ehrlich’s book The Population Bomb. This organization’s lawsuit against the Walt Disney Company spawned a dissent by William O. Douglas arguing that “the voice of the (*) inanimate object…should not be stilled” and calling for natural resources to have legal personhood. This group’s founder ended a friendship with Gifford Pinchot over the O’Shaughnessy Dam, which this group opposed in order to preserve the Hetch Hetchy Valley. For 10 points, name this environmental advocacy group co-founded by John Muir and named for a mountain range.
tossups.answer: Sierra Club

tossups.question: A soldier in this conflict “was a man already dead, a victim / of the” mortal “part that loved” in a poem titled for “The Triumph of” that man. Hands who fought in this conflict “had set no dancing-floor” before the speaker sees a “ragged urchin.” A mother “with shining breasts / Cried out in dismay” after looking for “Marble well-governed cities” in a poem about this conflict. In one poem, the sea reminds the speaker of the (*) “public fault” of a woman in this conflict. “Silence” is compared to a “catalogue of ships” from this conflict in the poem “Asphodel, That Greeny Flower.” The first known ekphrasis describes a shield in this conflict. A poem about this conflict starts, “Sing, Goddess, Achilles’s rage.” For 10 points, name this war caused by Helen’s abduction in The Iliad.
tossups.answer: Trojan War

tossups.question: In a 2008 meta-analysis, Takimoto et al. found that while the length of these structures was not affected by storm surges and other disturbances, their length was positively correlated with island size. Robert May’s expansion on Michael Rosenzweig’s hypothesized “paradox of enrichment” showed that an increase in the number of these structures negatively affects ecosystem stability. The (*) energetic hypothesis states that the length of these structures is limited by the efficiency of energy transfer within them. Toxins accumulate at higher levels of these structures as a result of biomagnification. These structures are combined to make food webs. For 10 points, name these linear paths demonstrating “who eats whom,” starting from producers and leading to apex predators.
tossups.answer: food chains [prompt on food webs until read by asking, “What components of food webs?”]

bonuses.leadin: This novel’s protagonist begins an affair with a Lebanese millionaire while working on a film adaptation of Henry James’s The Spoils of Poynton. For 10 points each:
answers: The Line of Beauty (by Alan Hollinghurst)
Margaret Thatcher [or Margaret Hilda Thatcher; accept Margaret Hilda Roberts]
Hilary Mantel [or Hilary Mary Mantel; accept Hilary Mary Thompson]
parts: Name this novel in which Nick Guest navigates his life as a gay man living with the conservative Fedden family.

In The Line of Beauty, a coked-out Nick dances with this Prime Minister at an anniversary party. In a controversial short story, an IRA member proclaims, “fucking rejoice!” before assassinating this “Iron Lady.”

“The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher” appears in a recent short story collection by this author. This author’s novel The Mirror and the Light concluded her monumental trilogy about the life of Thomas Cromwell.

bonuses.leadin: The standard growth medium Luria broth contains tryptone, yeast extract, and this compound. For 10 points each:
answers: Staphylococcus [accept Staphylococcus aureus or Staphylococcus epidermidis; prompt on S. aureus or S. epidermidis]
Vibrio fischeri [or V. fischeri; accept Aliivibrio fischeri or A. fischeri]
parts: Name this compound that may be iodized for human consumption. Extremophiles that thrive in regions with high concentrations of this ionic compound are called halophiles.

One species in this bacterial genus turns a pink medium that contains mannitol and a high salt concentration yellow. That species of this genus is coagulase-positive, while another member that colonizes the skin is not.

This bacteria, which colonizes the bobtail squid, is also typically cultured in salt-containing media. The lux operon system of this bacteria serves as a model for studies of quorum sensing and bioluminescence.

bonuses.leadin: After hearing a sermon delivered by Freeborn Garrettson, Stokely Sturgis converted to this denomination and allowed his slaves, including Richard Allen, to purchase their freedom. For 10 points each:
answers: Methodism [or Methodists; accept African Methodist Episcopal Church or AME]
Lee [accept Jarena Lee; accept Mother Ann Lee]
parts: Name this Protestant denomination that became the largest in the United States due to the efforts of circuit riders during the Second Great Awakening. This denomination was founded on the teachings of John Wesley.
After he gained his freedom and was ordained by Francis Asbury, Allen inaugurated the first independent black church in America, the African Methodist Episcopal Church, in this city in 1794.

Allen’s church sponsored the preaching of Jarena, a woman with this surname, who traveled nearly 2,000 miles per year. Another woman with this surname led the founding of the first Shaker community in America.

bonuses.leadin: While one composer wrote the first eight pieces of his Opus 6 in a form of this genre with a characteristic slow-fast-slow-fast framework, only one of them has a religious theme. For 10 points each:
answers: concerto grosso [prompt on concerto] (The unnamed subgenre is da chiesa.)
Christmas [accept Christmas Concerto or Concerto “For the Eve of Christmas” or Concerto “Fatto per la notte di Natale;” accept Christmas Oratorio]
parts: Name this genre, which includes a piece that opens with marcato B-flat minor and F-sharp diminished chords before a cello starts its G-minor grave (“GRAH-veh”) first movement. A ripieno accompanies pieces in this genre.

Pietro Ottoboni commissioned that Corelli concerto grosso “for the eve of” this holiday. J.S. Bach’s Ascension and Easter oratorios are grouped with an oratorio for this holiday that is associated with carols like “Silent Night.”

Corelli rocks the Infant Jesus to sleep in the last movement of his Christmas Concerto, written in this style ad libitum. In all Christmas concerti, an obligatory movement in this style evokes country shepherds playing the zampogna and pif ero.

bonuses.leadin: According to this philosopher, modal realism creates a “philosopher’s paradise” in the same way that a set-theoretic universe is a “mathematician’s paradise.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this thinker. His book On the Plurality of Worlds argues that, because it is incredibly theoretically fruitful to do so, we should take all possible worlds to be real in the same way as our “actual” world.

One objection to modal realism holds that, as in set theory, one of these situations arises when we imagine a possible world that contains all others. A “liar’s” one of these things arises from the statement “this sentence is false.”

The final chapter of On the Plurality of Worlds advances this view, which is analogous to perdurantism. This view holds that individuals exist in only one world, and are thus not identical with beings in any other world.

bonuses.leadin: In a story that continues the plot of this poem, Recabarren witnesses this poem’s protagonist die at the hand of a Black guitarist. For 10 points each:
answers: Argentina [or Argentine Republic or República Argentina] (The story in the lead-in is “The End” by Borges.)
Ocampo [accept Victoria Ocampo or Silvina Ocampo]
parts: Name this epic poem by José Hernández about the adventures of the title gaucho, who engages in payadas and kills a Black man in a knife fight.
Martín Fierro is set in this country. The short story “El Sur,” which parodied this country’s gaucho lifestyle, was written by its native author Jorge Luis Borges.

Borges’s story “El Sur” shares its name with a magazine published by an Argentine author with this surname. Another author with this surname was the only female editor of an anthology called The Book of Fantasy.

bonuses.leadin: The crust of these objects is thought to contain “nuclear pasta” which may be the strongest material in the universe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these extremely dense astronomical objects which are formed from supergiant stars that fall below the TOV limit and thus don’t form black holes.

Jocelyn Bell initially discovered pulsars while studying this segment of the electromagnetic spectrum. A device designed to observe this segment of the electromagnetic spectrum collapsed in December 2020.

A 2018 study by Zhang et al. proposed that the collapse of a strange neutron star’s crust could cause these radio phenomena. Duncan Laurier discovered these transient pulses of unknown origin while analyzing pulsar data.

bonuses.leadin: Qián Xuésēn (“chee-EN shoo-eh-SUN”) developed a launch vehicle named after this event to put China’s first satellite in orbit in 1970. For 10 points each:
answers: Iris Chang [or Chang Shun-Ru] (The other work is The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II.)
parts: The Yán'ān Rectification Movement followed this event, during which partisans regrouped in Shaanxi province. Edgar Snow drew upon his experience in this event to publish Red Star Over China.

Snow based his magnum opus on numerous interviews with this leader. After Qián Xuésēn was deported during the Second Red Scare, this first Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party employed him as the head of China’s space program.

This historian detailed Qián Xuésēn’s role in the development of the Chinese space program in Thread of the Silkworm. In another work, this historian criticized Iwane Matsui’s role in a “forgotten holocaust.”

bonuses.leadin: Fikret Berkes’s research focuses on how this expertise can be used to create environmental policy aimed towards adaptive management and resilience. For 10 points each:
answers: traditional ecological knowledge [accept traditional environmental knowledge; prompt on TEK]
parts: Give this three-word term used by anthropologists like Berkes, Darrell Posey, and Robin Wall Kimmerer to describe accumulated indigenous bodies of thought about resource management and local biodiversity.

Berkes describes how the Cree vary their equipment to manage this resource, which is farmed alongside rice throughout Southeast Asia. The Sámi collaborated with the Finnish government to manage declines in this resource.
Another key example of traditional ecological knowledge is the periodic renewal of landscapes using this technology. The use of this technology is alternated with “slashing” in jhum agriculture.

bonuses.leadin: Margaret Schütte-Lihotsky designed a kitchen with stain-resistant beech surfaces for use in one of these projects. For 10 points each:
answers: housing complexes [or public housing projects or apartment buildings; prompt on Habitat 67]
parts: Name these projects. Schütte-Lihotsky worked on one of them spearheaded by Ernst May in Frankfurt. Moshe Safdie used concrete blocks for another of these projects built for Expo 67 in Montreal.

In a fire station for this city, Susana Torre designed individual bedrooms in an attempt to shift bonding toward the kitchen and include women socially. Robert Venturi also designed a Modernist firehouse for this Indiana city.

This architect left the kitchen visible from dining spaces, as opposed to hidden away, in his open floor plan for the Usonian Willey House. This architect integrated a waterfall into his Fallingwater.

bonuses.leadin: The Turin Papyrus Map surveyed bekhen stone quarries and this metal’s quartz vein deposits. For 10 points each:
answers: libraries [or bibliotheca or bibliotheke; accept Library of Alexandria or Bibliotheca Alexandrina; accept Bibliotheca historica or Historical Library; prompt on Musaeum of Alexandria or Mouseion of Alexandria]
Erythraean Sea [accept On the Erythraean Sea or Peri tē̂s Erythrâs Thalássēs; accept Periplus of the Erythraean Sea or Períplous tē̂s Erythrâs Thalássēs or Periplus Maris Erythraei]
parts: Name this metal that was mined south of Egypt according to Diodorus Siculus’s magnum opus. The Lydians heated alloys found in the Pactolus River with salt and brick dust to purify this metal via cementation.
Diodorus’s wide-ranging world history shares a title with these places. Ptolemy I Soter established one of these places in Alexandria that housed a large collection of papyrus scrolls.

Diodorus rehashed many observations made by Agatharchides of Cnidus in the latter’s five-volume history on this body of water. An unknown first-century Greek merchant discusses trade secrets around the Horn of Africa in a work titled for this body of water, which is associated with the modern-day Red Sea.

bonuses.leadin: Two of Laura Knight’s designs featuring circus performers won a 1930s contest to appear on one company’s Famous Artists series of packaging for this substance. For 10 points each:
answers: chocolate (The Famous Artists series was produced by Cadbury.)
parts: Name this substance, boxes of which can be used to describe crowd-pleasing, overly sentimental paintings. A cup of this substance is served alongside a glass of water by a pink-bonneted maid in a Jean-Étienne Liotard pastel.

Toadstool pixies surround a child in a Cadbury design by Arthur Rackham, known for his fantastical works for this purpose. Aubrey Beardsley’s black-and-white works for this purpose include Salome holding up a dripping head.

This artist’s popular “six-footer” landscapes earned him a reputation as a chocolate-box artist. Confectionery tins often feature this artist’s painting of Willy Lott’s cottage as three horses pull the title Hay Wain across a river.

bonuses.leadin: If the aldehyde used in this reaction has alpha-hydrogens, it will occur more slowly than aldol condensation. For 10 points each:
answers: disproportionation reaction [accept dismutation reaction; prompt on redox or oxidation-reduction]
hydride [or H-minus; do not accept “H” or “H-plus”]
parts: In the presence of a strong base or Lewis acid, [read slowly] a non-enolizable aldehyde can oxidize another molecule of the aldehyde to a carboxylic acid, and is itself reduced to a primary alcohol in what reaction?
The maximum yield of the primary alcohol from the Cannizzaro reaction is 50% because it is one of these reactions, in which a reagent is simultaneously oxidized and reduced.
Another way to reduce an aldehyde to a primary alcohol uses reagents that deliver this nucleophilic group. Reagents that deliver this anionic hydrogen group include DIBAL-H.

bonuses.leadin: In one essay, this author recalls herself using the phrase “No waste money that way” when talking to her mother, and doesn’t like describing that English is “broken” or “fractured.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Woman Warrior: Memoirs of a Girlhood Among Ghosts
Sūn Wùkōng [accept the Monkey King; prompt on Tripmaster Monkey: His Fake Book]
parts: Name this author of the essay “Mother Tongue,” in which her mother describes this author’s novel, The Joy Luck Club, as “so easy to read.”

In this novel, the protagonist’s mother claims she cut part of her daughter’s tongue to help her speak. The protagonist’s aunt kills herself after giving birth in a pigsty in this novel’s chapter “No-Name Woman.”

Maxine Hong Kingston, who wrote The Woman Warrior, alludes to this figure in the title of a book about Wittman Ah Sing. The graphic novel American Born Chinese reimagines when this figure stole the emperor’s wine after being excluded from a divine banquet.

bonuses.leadin: You are a sofer. Answer the following about things that you do before you write a new Torah scroll, for 10 points each.
parts: You first have a rabbi inspect your parchment and certify it as this status. Your thread and quill also come from animals with this designation, which also describes “clean” food products that bear an OU or K symbol.

You then go to one of these baths to purify yourself before you touch your quill, and you will return to it each time you write God’s name. Niddah, or menstruating Orthodox women, must also cleanse themselves in these baths before reassociating with their husbands.

Finally, you test your quill by writing this people’s name and crossing it out. Thus you fulfill the mitzvah of “blotting out” this people, whom the Israelites defeated at Rephidim when Aaron and Hur held up Moses’s hands.

bonuses.leadin: It’s not Vegetius, but this author defined a “just war” as one fought to achieve peace without such “detestable and improper” acts like pillaging and harming non-combatants. For 10 points each:
answers: The Romance of the Rose [or Le Roman de la Rose]
parts: Name this author of The Book of Feats of Arms and Chivalry. Reason, Rectitude, and Justice help this author build the title structure in The Book of the City of Ladies.

The Book of the City of Ladies was partially written in response to Jean de Meun’s addition to this chivalric poem. At the end of this poem, Venus defeats Danger and Jealousy, allowing the Lover to pick the title flower.

Pizan likely used this author’s On Famous Women as reference material for The Book of the City of Ladies. Several Florentines who have fled the black plague tell stories in this author’s book The Decameron.

bonuses.leadin: In one manifestation, this figure ferries souls to the Pure Land in the “Ship of Salvation,” contributing to her identification with the Catholic Our Lady of Charity. For 10 points each:
answers: Santería [or La Regla de Ocha or Lucumí]
parts: Name this bodhisattva of compassion. Images of this goddess of mercy, who often wields a willow branch and a vial of water, can also be found on altars to Oshún.
Another deity, Guān Yǔ, was syncretized as San Fancón with Saint Barbara and this orisha, whose colors are red and white. This orisha wields a double-headed ax.

Indentured Chinese laborers syncretized Guānyīn and Guān Yǔ with the orishas and saints in this Cuban religion. The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of adherents of this religion to sacrifice chickens.

bonuses.leadin: A Pulitzer Prize-winning book by David Kertzer details the influence of this organization in interwar European politics, exposing its ambivalence towards Jewish persecution. For 10 points each:
answers: Roman Catholic Church [accept the Vatican or the Papacy or the Holy See; prompt on Christian Church or the Church]
Benito Mussolini [or Benito Amilcare Andrea Mussolini; accept Il Duce]
Gentile [accept Emilio Gentile or Giovanni Gentile]
parts: Name this organization that Pius XI administered until his death in 1939.

Kertzer titled his book for Pope Pius XI and this leader. Pius XI criticized this leader’s suppression of Catholic Youth Organizations in the “We Do Not Need” encyclical, after he recognized this leader in the Lateran Pacts.

In “Fascism as a Political Religion,” a thinker with this surname coined the term “sacralization of politics” to describe how Mussolini promoted the title construct to counter the Catholic Church’s influence in Italian society. Another thinker with this surname ghost-wrote much of Mussolini’s “The Doctrine of Fascism.”

bonuses.leadin: James V. Neel posited the now-rejected “thrifty gene” hypothesis to suggest an evolutionary advantage for some Native American populations to suffer from this disorder because of historical “feast and famine” cycles. For 10 points each:
answers: type 2 diabetes mellitus [or T2D; prompt on diabetes mellitus or DM]
parts: Name this disorder. The Indian Health Service aims to decrease metformin treatment costs for this disorder to address high rates among tribal nations in the United States.

The prevalence of food deserts, regions with little access to this type of store, in Native American reservations contributes to high rates of type 2 diabetes. There are only thirteen examples of this type of store in the Navajo Nation, including zero Krogers or Whole Foods.

This thinker linked both thrifty genes and Coca-colonization to high rates of type 2 diabetes among the Akimel O’odham (“AH-kim-uhl OH-oh-dahm”), or Pima people, in “The Double Puzzle of Diabetes.” This thinker expanded those arguments into a chapter of The World Until Yesterday.

bonuses.leadin: Placing different configurations of resistors and capacitors in the paths of these circuit elements allows them to do things like compare and add voltages. For 10 points each:
answers: op-amps [or operational amplifiers; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these analog circuit elements, which are symbolized by a triangle. They magnify the voltage difference between their inverting and non-inverting inputs.

Placing a capacitor in the feedback path of an op-amp creates a circuit element that performs this operation, since the magnitude of the output voltage depends on the length of time a voltage is present at the input.

Applying positive feedback to the non-inverting input of an op-amp creates a Schmitt trigger, which converts analog signals to these signals. Unlike analog signals, these signals only take on discrete values.
